projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: AN Act and Declaration OF THE COMMON COÆ²NCEL Of the City of LONDON, Touching the late INSURRECTION: WITH An ORDER of the Lords and Commons aÅ¿Å¿embled in Parliament, For a Publique ThankÅ¿giving to be made on the next Lords-day, within the late Lines of Communication, for the great Mercy of God in delivering the City of of London from the late horrid Outrage and Tumult.

p.hi: ORdered by the Commans aÅ¿Å¿embled in Parliament, That the Act of the Common Councel upon the late InÅ¿urrection, be printed, and read on the next Lords-day, when Thanks is appointed to be given to Almighty God, the Author of this great Deliverance from the Å¿aid late InÅ¿urrection.

closer.signed: H: ElÅ¿ynge, Cler. Parl. D. Com.

div.p: London, Printed for Edward HuÅ¿band, Printer to the Honorable HouÅ¿e of Commons. April 14. 1648.

div.head: Die Jovis, 13. April, 1648.
div.p: THat this HouÅ¿e doth approve of the Act of the Common Councel, touching the late InÅ¿urrection.

THat the Act of the Common Councel upon the late InÅ¿urrection, be printed, and read on the nexts Lord Day, when thanks is appointed to be given to Almighty God, the Author of this great deliverance from the Å¿aid late InÅ¿urrection.

closer.signed: H: ElÅ¿ynge, Cler. Parl. D. Com.

div.head: Die Jovis, 13. April, 1648.
div.p: ORdered by the Lords and Commons in Parliament aÅ¿Å¿embled, That a publique Thanksgiving be made by the Å¿everal MiniÅ¿ters within the late Lines of Communication, on the next Lords Day, for the great mercy of God, in delivering the City of London from the late horrid Outrage and Tumult; And that the Lord Major of the Å¿aid City do give notice thereof to the Å¿everal Ministers within the Å¿aid Lines of Communication.

closer.signed: H: ElÅ¿ynge, Cler. Parl. D. Com.

div.head:
Commune Concilium tentum in Camera Guihald Civitatis London undecimo die Aprilis, 1648. Anno
que regni Domini noÅ¿tri Caroli nunc regis Angliae, &c. viceÅ¿imo quarto coram Johanne Warner Majore civit' London, &c.
div.p:
AT this Common Councel, Mr. Alderman Fowk and Mr. Alderman Gibs, by the directions of the Committee of the Militia of London, did make a large Relation of the great Tumult, InÅ¿urrection and Mutiny which hapned in this City on the laÅ¿t Lords day, and on Munday laÅ¿t, by many evil diÅ¿poÅ¿ed perÅ¿ons, which firÅ¿t began on the Lords-day in the afternoon in the County of MiddleÅ¿ex, where they Å¿eized the Colours of one of the Trained-Bands of the Å¿aid County, who were there imployed for the Å¿uppreÅ¿Å¿ing of Å¿uch perÅ¿ons as did profane the Lords-day; and being diÅ¿perÅ¿ed by Å¿ome of the Generals Forces, did gather together within the City of London and Liberties thereof, and in a Riotous maner did break open divers houÅ¿es and Magazines of Arms and Ammunition, and took away Arms, Plate, Money and other things, and did Å¿eize upon the Drums of the Trained-Bands of this City, which were beating to raiÅ¿e their Companies, and armed themÅ¿elves, and beat up Drums, and put themÅ¿elves
in a warlike poÅ¿ture, and Å¿eized upon the Gates, Chains and Watches of this City, and then marched to the Lord Majors houÅ¿e, and there aÅ¿Å¿aulted the Lord Major, Sheriffs, Committee of the Militia of London, and other MagiÅ¿trates of â¢â¢ e Å¿ame; and did Å¿hoot into the Lord Majors houÅ¿e, beat back his Guards, killed one of them, wounded divers others, and Å¿eized and took away a piece of Ordnance from thence, with which they did afterwards Å¿lay and wound divers perÅ¿ons, and committed many other Outrages: All which matters being largely debated, and many particulars inÅ¿iÅ¿ted upon, both for the DiÅ¿covery and PuniÅ¿hment of the Å¿aid MiÅ¿demeanors and Outrages; and alÅ¿o for the preventing of the like for time to come, It was at the laÅ¿t concluded and agreed by this Common Councel as followeth:

FirÅ¿t, This Common Councel doth generally conceive that this City was in great danger, by reaÅ¿on of the Å¿aid Outrages and MiÅ¿demeanors, and that if the Å¿ame had not Å¿o timely been prevented and Å¿tayed, the whole City would have been expoÅ¿ed to the fury and rage of the Å¿aid Malefactors. And this Common Councel doth Declare, That the Å¿ame MiÅ¿demeanor and Outrage was a horrid and deteÅ¿table act, tending to the deÅ¿truction of the City, and that they do diÅ¿avow the Å¿ame, and with an utter deteÅ¿tation do Declare their diÅ¿like thereof. And this Common Councel do appoint the Committee of the Militia of London to make the Å¿ame known to the Honorable
HouÅ¿es of Parliament, and alÅ¿o to make an humble RequeÅ¿t unto them, That an Order may be iÅ¿Å¿ued forth from them to the Å¿everal MiniÅ¿ters of this City and the places adjacent, that they may be directed to give publique Thanks ãâã Almighty God, the Author of this great and wonderfu â¢ deliverance from that imminent danger wherein this City and parts adjacent were involved. And further, the Å¿aid Committee are appointed by this Court, to apply themÅ¿elves to the Honorable HouÅ¿es of Parliament, for the obtaining of a Å¿pecial CommiÅ¿Å¿ion of Oyer and Terminer, for the trying and puniÅ¿hing of all the Malefactors that had a hand in this deteÅ¿table action, according to the known Laws of this Land. And this Court with thankful hearts do acknowledge the inÅ¿truments under God, by which they obtained this Deliverance, to be by the Forces raiÅ¿ed and continued by the Parliament, under the command of his Excellency the Lord General Fairfax; and to manifeÅ¿t the Å¿ame, this Common Councel do alÅ¿o Order, That the Å¿aid Committee of the Militia, in the Name of the City, as a thing agreed upon by an unanimous conÅ¿ent, Å¿hall return their hearty Thanks to his Excellency, for his Å¿peedy and Å¿eaÅ¿onable Ayd afforded unto the City in this their great Å¿traight and danger. And this Court with a general conÅ¿ent, do well approve of the Endeavors of the Å¿aid Committee of the Militia for London, for the raiÅ¿ing of the Forces of the City, and in their procuring of the Å¿aid ayd and help from his Excellency in this Extremity,
and what elÅ¿e they have done for the appeaÅ¿ing and Å¿uppreÅ¿Å¿ing of the Å¿aid Tumults. And this Court do give Thanks to the Å¿aid Committee of the Militia, for their care and pains by them taken upon this Å¿ad occaÅ¿ion: And they do appoint Mr. Alderman Fowk to declare the Å¿ame their Thanks to Å¿uch of the Å¿aid Committee as are not of this Court. And this Court doth alÅ¿o with all thankfulneÅ¿s acknowledge the pains and care of the Right Honorable the Lord Major, and the Right WorÅ¿hipful the Sheriffs of this City therein. And this Court do generally Declare, That it is the duty of every Citizen of this City, by himÅ¿elf and all that do belong unto him, or is under his command, to be ready upon all occaÅ¿ions to be ayding and aÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿ting unto the Lord Major, and the reÅ¿t of the MagiÅ¿trates of this City, for the Å¿uppreÅ¿Å¿ing of all Tumults and DiÅ¿orders within the Å¿ame. And the Å¿everal perÅ¿ons now preÅ¿ent at this Common Councel, by the holding up of their hands have promiÅ¿ed, That for the time to come they will uÅ¿e their utmoÅ¿t endeavor, and be ready upon all occaÅ¿ions to do the Å¿ame.
